title: The New Kid in Robotics Club

chapters.text: Jake stood frozen at the doorway of the robotics club, clutching his backpack straps so tightly his knuckles turned white. Twenty pairs of eyes stared back at him. The room buzzed with the sounds of small motors and excited chatter that instantly died when he appeared. A tall girl with bright blue hair stepped forward. "You lost?" she asked, raising an eyebrow. Jake swallowed hard. This was his third school this year, and he'd promised himself he'd finally find his people. "I'm Jake. New kid. I like building things." The blue-haired girl exchanged glances with a boy wearing a NASA t-shirt. They seemed to communicate silently before she broke into a wide grin. "Perfect timing! Mia just moved away and we need someone for our competition team. I'm Zoe." She extended her hand, but Jake couldn't miss the whispers from the corner of the room.

Jake hesitated before shaking her hand, his eyes darting to the group of students huddled in the corner. Their whispers grew louder as one tall boy with glasses pointed at Jake's worn-out sneakers. The robotics classroom smelled like solder and plastic, with half-built machines scattered across tables. Jake took a deep breath and stepped forward anyway, following the girl toward a workstation where a small robot with blinking lights sat unfinished. On the table next to it, someone had left an empty milk carton from lunch. Jake accidentally bumped it with his elbow, sending it tumbling to the floor. The whispers turned to snickers, and Jake's face burned hot with embarrassment. But instead of running away, he bent down, picked up the carton, tossed it in the recycling bin, and turned his attention to the robot, determined to prove he belonged there.

Jake examined the robot on the table, noticing its unfinished frame and loose wires. The other club members watched silently as he carefully touched a disconnected sensor. "This goes here," he said quietly, connecting it to the main circuit board. The robot's lights blinked to life, and a few students gasped. Mr. Wilson, the club advisor, stepped forward with an impressed smile. "Looks like our new member knows his stuff," he announced. Jake felt his shoulders relax as a tall girl with curly hair moved aside, making space for him at the workbench. She pointed to a box of parts that included gears, screws, and even a small metal piece shaped like a crown. "We're building a rescue robot for the state competition," she explained. "Want to help with the navigation system?" Jake nodded and pulled up a chair, finally feeling like he might find his place in this room.

Jake sat down and looked at the robot parts scattered across the table. The other students quickly went back to their projects, the sound of clicking and whirring filling the room. A girl with curly hair slid a box of gears toward him. "I'm Mia," she said. "We're building rescue robots this month." Jake picked up a small motor and turned it in his hands. For the first time since moving to this school, he didn't feel like a complete outsider. Mr. Chen, the club teacher, walked over with a notebook and a smile. "Everyone needs a partner," he announced, scanning the room. "Jake, would you like to work with Mia? She's our best programmer." Mia grinned and pointed to her robot design. Jake noticed a tiny protective covering on top of her robot model. "Is that a safety shield?" he asked. "Yeah," Mia nodded. "Every good robot needs protection."

Jake nodded in agreement, his grip on his backpack finally loosening. "Every good robot needs protection," he repeated, remembering what his dad always said about engineering. The robotics club members seemed impressed by his comment. A tall girl with curly hair waved him over to an empty seat beside her workstation. Jake shuffled across the room, trying not to bump into the tables covered with metal parts, wires, and tools. The club was working on small battle robots with protective shields and armor plates. Some robots even had special bumpers that looked like paws to grip objects. Jake sat down nervously as the girl introduced herself as Mia, the club president. She handed him a small toolkit and a sheet of instructions. For the first time since entering the room, Jake felt a smile spread across his face. Maybe this robotics club wouldn't be so scary after all.

Jake took a deep breath and stepped further into the room. The robotics teacher, Mr. Wilson, waved him over to an empty seat next to a girl with curly hair who was working on what looked like a small robot arm. "Everyone, this is Jake, our newest member," Mr. Wilson announced. The girl smiled at Jake and introduced herself as Mia. She showed him the project their team was building for the upcoming competition. Jake noticed other students working with wires, circuit boards, and metal parts across the tables. Some robots beeped and moved around the floor while their creators cheered. The nervous feeling in Jake's stomach started to fade as Mia handed him a screwdriver and pointed to a loose screw on their robot. He carefully tightened it, feeling a small sense of accomplishment when the arm moved smoothly afterward.

Jake smiled as the robot arm responded to his adjustments. The other club members nodded approvingly, and Ms. Chen, the robotics teacher, gave him a thumbs up from across the room. Over the past few weeks, Jake had gone from nervous newcomer to valued team member. His careful work on the robot's mobility system had helped solve problems that had stumped the group for days. As the team gathered their things at the end of the meeting, Zoe handed Jake the team jacket they'd all signed. "Official robotics nerd now," she laughed. Walking home that afternoon, Jake no longer gripped his backpack straps with anxiety. Instead, he wore his new jacket proudly, thinking about the competition next month and all the friends he'd made. The doorway that once seemed so intimidating now felt like the entrance to exactly where he belonged.
